pullRequest.body:
- Define the derivative `f.linearDeriv` of a multilinear map `f` at `x`, i.e. the first-order term of `f(x+h)-f(x+h')`.
- Define `MultilinearMap.domDomRestrict`: given a multilinear map indexed by a type `ι`, a function `P: ι → Prop` and a vector `z` define on `{a // ¬ P a}`, this is the multilinear map indexed by `{a // P a}`  sending `x` to the value of `f` at the vector that has coordinate at `a : ι` equal to `x a` if `P a` and `z a` if ` ¬ P a`.

- [x] depends on: #9137

---

A very minor point: we don't put a space before the first `(`.

I pushed another file to my branch and it got added to the PR, even though that was not my intention (this other file needs some work before it can become a PR). Does anybody know how to reverse this, without touching the first file ?

I've discarded that file. Regarding what you attempt to do in the file: we have [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt) and [AnalyticAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#AnalyticAt) is defined in terms of [ContinuousMultilinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/Multilinear/Basic.html#ContinuousMultilinearMap). So I guess it shouldn't be hard to get what you want through that route?

> I've discarded that file. Regarding what you attempt to do in the file: we have [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt) and [AnalyticAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#AnalyticAt) is defined in terms of [ContinuousMultilinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/Multilinear/Basic.html#ContinuousMultilinearMap). So I guess it shouldn't be hard to get what you want through that route?

It depends what you mean by "not hard"; mathematically it's very easy, but in Lean it might be a pain. Certainly if I had known that analytic functions were in mathlib, I would have tried to go that route, because this is the best way. (And yes, I did ask about what I wanted to do on Zulip before starting.)

Okay, I know what to do, I hope it won't be too painful.

I found [your Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Differentiability.20of.20bounded.20multilinear.20maps.20.3F) (cc @ocfnash) and I do recall seeing it before. However, I had no idea Analytic is defined in terms of multilinear maps, even though I did know it's in mathlib. I only became aware 2 weeks ago due to my involvement in the Hairer challenge, when I looked up the definition of Analytic when proving [evaluations of multivariate polynomials are analytic](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9138/commits/a285b7d9f14cab1758e6b483b3c2ce3843aea59c#diff-bfe5d0518e7c120eede815999c537da5265deb6dc656d384628065d022d2969fR311-R317). Sorry for being unable to connect the dots earlier and for the extra work!

> I found [your Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Differentiability.20of.20bounded.20multilinear.20maps.20.3F) (cc @ocfnash) and I do recall seeing it before. However, I had no idea Analytic is defined in terms of multilinear maps, even though I did know it's in mathlib. I only became aware 2 weeks ago due to my involvement in the Hairer challenge, when I looked up the definition of Analytic when proving [evaluations of multivariate polynomials are analytic](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9138/commits/a285b7d9f14cab1758e6b483b3c2ce3843aea59c#diff-bfe5d0518e7c120eede815999c537da5265deb6dc656d384628065d022d2969fR311-R317). Sorry for being unable to connect the dots earlier and for the extra work!

Eh, it's not your fault. So anyway, I proved that continuous multilinear maps are analytic, however, to deduce that they are differentiable, I need the target space F to be complete ! At least that's a hypothesis in [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt), I haven't checked whether it's possible to remove it. 
But my old proof works without that extra hypothesis on F ! So I guess I should still PR it, and also PR the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic, now that it's written ?

That's nice! I only just worked out the informal argument why a continuous multilinear form f (of finitely many factors) is analytic; you need to compose it with the (linear) projections to obtain f(p1, ..., pn) and put that as the nth term in the power series. As for the completeness assumption, I think it's removable and [FormalMultilinearSeries.changeOrigin_eval](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.changeOrigin_eval) seems to be the key lemma to generalize. I'll try later if you don't beat me to it!

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#9137~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I now realized that the derivative of an analytic function may not even exist if the space isn't complete, let alone continuously differentiable; the original series converging can't guarantee the derivative doesn't fall into a hole. So I think your result for continuous linear maps will be a valuable addition to mathlib! Maybe we could generalize it to analytic functions with finitely many nonzero terms ("polynomial functions"?). As a different project, the derivative's power series is in mathlib as [FormalMultilinearSeries.shift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FormalMultilinearSeries.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.shift), but apparently no one has shown it evaluates to the derivative yet ...

Maybe we can still make use of the proofs of the Analytic lemmas; you may try to replace the CompleteSpace conditions by the necessary Summable conditions. Then they'll apply to both CompleteSpaces (where we can use [Summable.of_norm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/InfiniteSum.html#Summable.of_norm)) and our situation ("polynomial functions"), where we have summability by virtue of being finite sums.

Yes, the completeness is only really used to prove the convergence of infinite power series. So maybe the simplest would be to have some HasFiniteFPowerSeriesOnBall structure which would cover both polynomial and multilinear functions. This should be stable by taking derivatives, and so we would get both analyticity and differentiability results with any completeness condition. I won't get to it today as I have a pretty full schedule.
By the way, the "continuous multilinear functions are analytic" code is [there](https://github.com/smorel394/ExteriorPowers/blob/master/ExteriorPowers/ContinuousMultilinearMapContDiff.lean).

Ok, I added some more stuff to prepare for the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic: the definition of what will be the formal multilinear series at `x` and a proof that it does calculate `f (x + y)` (with a finite sum). Also, the comparison of the degree `1` term with the previously defined derivative. I kept the previous derivative, because it definition doesn't use a linear order on `ι`, while the definition of the formal multilinear series does.

Also, I kept running into merge problems that for some reason duplicated the new code, so I hope that those are resolved now. It seems to be okay. And I broke mathlib in my branch when trying to update it (again :-(((( ), so nothing compiles locally for me, but I did check the new code in another lean project, and again hopefully it's okay. Now I'll try to fix my local mathlib.
Yeah, it's not okay, the thing didn't build. Why do I break stuff every time I update mathlib ? I only wanted the new lemma from PR #9137. :-(
(the base branches above are to work around a github quirk caused by a weird (but ultimately harmless) merge that you did)

Okay, after last night's git drama, and after a lot of help from Eric, and after I accidentally pushed the whole of mathlib4 to a mathlib3 branch, it seems that I have finally been able to successfully update this. So I added some code to prepare for the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic: the definition of what will be the formal multilinear series at x, i.e. the higher derivatives, and a proof that it does calculate f (x + y) (with a finite sum). Also, the comparison of the degree 1 term with the previously defined derivative. I kept the previous derivative, because it definition doesn't use a linear order on ι, while the definition of the formal multilinear series does.

As the new code uses things like `MultilinearMap.domDomCongr`, I moved it down in the file so it would come after that, and put it in its own section called 'Derivative`.

I think this lemma is till true if you replace `s.orderIsoOfFin hs` with `σ : Fin s.card ≃ s` (or perhaps keep `n` and use  `σ : Fin n ≃ s`) throughout, and will be a bit easier to read as a result.
This was superseded by alreadydone's simplification.

I changed the statement a bit and golfed it with two lemmas; I've PR'd the first as #9137.
```
open Finset in
theorem _root_.Finset.powersetCard_one {α} [DecidableEq α] {s : Finset α} :
    s.powersetCard 1 = s.map ⟨_, Finset.singleton_injective⟩ := by
  ext t
  rw [mem_powersetCard, card_eq_one, mem_map, ← exists_and_left, exists_congr]
  intro a
  rw [eq_comm, ← s.singleton_subset_iff, and_congr_left_eq]; rfl
  rintro rfl; rfl

open Finset in
lemma map_add_eq_map_add_linearDeriv_add [DecidableEq ι] [Fintype ι] (x h : (i : ι) → M₁ i) : 
    f (x + h) = f x + f.linearDeriv x h +
      ∑ s in univ.powerset.filter (2 ≤ ·.card), f (s.piecewise h x) := by
  rw [add_comm, map_add_univ, ← Finset.powerset_univ,
      ← sum_filter_add_sum_filter_not _ (2 ≤ ·.card)]
  simp_rw [not_le, Nat.lt_succ, le_iff_lt_or_eq (b := 1), Nat.lt_one_iff, filter_or,
    ← powersetCard_eq_filter, sum_union (univ.pairwise_disjoint_powersetCard zero_ne_one),
    powersetCard_zero, powersetCard_one, sum_singleton, Finset.piecewise_empty, sum_map,
    Function.Embedding.coeFn_mk, Finset.piecewise_singleton, linearDeriv_apply, add_comm]

open Finset in
lemma map_add_sub_map_add_sub_linearDeriv [DecidableEq ι] [Fintype ι] (x h h' : (i : ι) → M₁ i) :
    f (x + h) - f (x + h') - f.linearDeriv x (h - h') =
    ∑ s in univ.powerset.filter (2 ≤ ·.card), (f (s.piecewise h x) - f (s.piecewise h' x)) := by
  simp_rw [map_add_eq_map_add_linearDeriv_add, add_assoc, add_sub_add_comm, sub_self, zero_add,
    ← LinearMap.map_sub, add_sub_cancel', sum_sub_distrib]
```
Made the change and pushed, thanks !

I don't understand why this is not stated with simply `f a - f b` as the LHS, without mentioning a Finset `s` at all. When `a` only differ from `b` on a Finset `s`, all summands outside of `s` would vanish by linearity, and you get a sum over `s.card` terms, and I think you can still get estimates as easily. Choosing an Equiv between `ι` and some `Fin n` is also a good idea, like Eric suggested.

Okay, I now see that induction on the Finset `s` is probably the easiest way to prove such statements, and we also don't want to restrict ourselves to finite `ι`. I have been able to give a short proof to an almost identical version of your result which however doesn't require an Equiv with `Fin n`. ~~The version with two `piecewise` can be obtained by combining two copies of `map_sub_map` below.~~
```
lemma map_update [DecidableEq ι] (x : (i : ι) → M₁ i) (i : ι) (v : M₁ i)  :
    f (update x i v) = f x - f (update x i (x i - v)) := by
  rw [map_sub, update_eq_self, sub_sub_cancel]

open Finset in
lemma map_sub_map_piecewise [LinearOrder ι] (a b : (i : ι) → M₁ i) (s : Finset ι) :
    f a - f (s.piecewise b a) =
    ∑ i in s, f (fun j ↦ if j ∈ s → j < i then a j else if i = j then a j - b j else b j) := by
  refine s.induction_on_min ?_ fun k s hk ih ↦ ?_
  · rw [Finset.piecewise_empty, sum_empty, sub_self]
  rw [Finset.piecewise_insert, map_update, ← sub_add, ih,
      add_comm, sum_insert (lt_irrefl _ <| hk k ·)]
  simp_rw [s.mem_insert]
  congr 1
  · congr; ext i; split_ifs with h₁ h₂
    · rw [update_noteq, Finset.piecewise_eq_of_not_mem]
      · exact fun h ↦ (hk i h).not_lt (h₁ <| .inr h)
      · exact fun h ↦ (h₁ <| .inl h).ne h
    · cases h₂
      rw [update_same, s.piecewise_eq_of_not_mem _ _ (lt_irrefl _ <| hk k ·)]
    · push_neg at h₁
      rw [update_noteq (Ne.symm h₂), s.piecewise_eq_of_mem _ _ (h₁.1.resolve_left <| Ne.symm h₂)]
  · apply sum_congr rfl; intro i hi; congr; ext j; congr 1; apply propext
    simp_rw [imp_iff_not_or, not_or]; apply or_congr_left'
    intro h; rw [and_iff_right]; rintro rfl; exact h (hk i hi)

lemma map_piecewise_sub_map_piecewise [LinearOrder ι] (a b v : (i : ι) → M₁ i) (s : Finset ι) :
    f (s.piecewise a v) - f (s.piecewise b v) = ∑ i in s, f
      fun j ↦ if j ∈ s then if j < i then a j else if j = i then a j - b j else b j else v j := by
  rw [← s.piecewise_idem_right b a, map_sub_map_piecewise]
  refine Finset.sum_congr rfl fun i hi ↦ congr_arg f <| funext fun j ↦ ?_
  by_cases hjs : j ∈ s
  · rw [if_pos hjs]; by_cases hji : j < i
    · rw [if_pos fun _ ↦ hji, if_pos hji, s.piecewise_eq_of_mem _ _ hjs]
    rw [if_neg (not_imp.mpr ⟨hjs, hji⟩), if_neg hji]
    obtain rfl | hij := eq_or_ne i j
    · rw [if_pos rfl, if_pos rfl, s.piecewise_eq_of_mem _ _ hi]
    · rw [if_neg hij, if_neg hij.symm]
  · rw [if_neg hjs, if_pos fun h ↦ (hjs h).elim, s.piecewise_eq_of_not_mem _ _ hjs]
```
Sorry, not by combining two copies, but by substitution (piecewise twice is the same as piecewise once). Updated my code above.

Thanks ! Let me test it with the rest of the project (this is only a technical lemma used in a larger proof that continuous multilinear maps are differentiable, so I need it to work with the rest of the proof), and I'll get back to you.
Yup it works, it actually simplifies the proof of the later results. :-) I'm rewriting the file to integrate your changes, thanks !
Made the changes and pushed.

Sorry, this doesn't actually work, probably because `x` isn't a non-dependent function. Let me change it back.
```suggestion
lemma linearDeriv_apply [DecidableEq ι] [Fintype ι] (f : MultilinearMap R M₁ M₂)
    (x y : (i : ι) → M₁ i) :
    f.linearDeriv x y = ∑ i, f (update x i (y i)) := by
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (x : (i : ι) → M i) (s : Set ι) [(i : ι) → Decidable (i ∈ s)] (y : (i : ι) → M i) : ```
This looks like a bad merge

Are you sure you don't want
```suggestion
    MultilinearMap R (fun (i : s) => M₁ i) M₂ where
```
which avoids the "diagonalization" of `z`, replacing `z ⟨i, h⟩ i` with `z ⟨i, h⟩` below?

I eventually want a [FormalMultilinearSeries](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FormalMultilinearSeries.html#FormalMultilinearSeries) that sums to `f`, when the multilinear map `f` is also continuous. As `f` is a map from `(i : ι) → M₁ i` to `M₂`, the nth term of the FormalMultilinearSeries must be a multilinear map on `Fin n →((i : ι) → M₁ i)` (and then we evaluate it on the diagonal when we sum). This was the most direct way I found to do that.

I wonder if I might do what I want to do in another way, which would avoid the ugly definition that you point out and avoid the choice of the linear order. I need to write stuff down on paper.

So I don't need to choose an order on `ι`, just an equivalence of each `s` of cardinality `n` with `Fin n`. Which choice is ugliest is up for debate. The mathematical point hiding behind that is that the nth derivative is not unique in positive characteristic. (In characteristic 0, I could just take the symmetrization of the thing I defined and divide by `n!`.)
As for the original question, yes, I could start by defining a multilinear map on `(i : s) → M₁ i` and build the nth derivative from that. I guess the auxiliary construction could be independently interesting, so let me try.
Yes, I think my claim is mainly "you could factor this through the definition I propose", and that the factored definition could be called `domDomRestrict`
Working on it right now.
Done. Now let's see what CI makes of this.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · rw [h, Function.update_same] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · rw [Function.update_noteq h] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · simp only [h', ne_eq, dite_true] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · simp only [h', ne_eq, dite_false] ```

```suggestion
is `f` evaluated at the vector with `i`th coordinate `z i` if `i ∈ s` and `x i` otherwise.-/
```

How much messier do things become if you generalize to
```suggestion
def domDomRestrict [DecidableEq ι] (f : MultilinearMap R M₁ M₂) (x : (i : ↥sᶜ) → M₁ i)
    (s : Set ι) [(i : ι) → Decidable (i ∈ s)] :
    MultilinearMap R (fun (i : s) => M₁ i) M₂ where
  toFun z := f (fun i ↦ if h : i ∈ s then z ⟨i, h⟩ else x ⟨i, h⟩)
```

Not sure. I'm nervous because of things like [this](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Multilinear/Basic.html#MultilinearMap.toLinearMap), where you take `m` defined on all of `ι` even though you don't actually have to. (Mathematically it doesn't matter what we choose here.)
Doesn't seem to change much. I can make the change, I'm pretty indifferent to it, just not sure what is more compatible with standard mathlib practice.
Made the change.

```suggestion
  ∑ s : univ.powersetLen n,
```
seems more appropriate here
Lean does not seem to know that definition, I get an error ("invalid field 'powersetLen', the environment does not contain 'Finset.powersetLen'"). I also cannot find `Finset.powersetLen` in mathlib.
Oh, I think I mean `powersetCard`
I made the change, it does simplify things a bit.

```suggestion
```
Can you use the `compl` notation here, as in my original suggestion?

If you mean the notation `sᶜ`, no I can't. I get an error message 
```
failed to synthesize instance
  HasCompl (Type uι)
```
and I don't know how to get rid of it.

```suggestion
    [DecidableEq s] (x : (i : ↥sᶜ)→ M₁ i) (z : (i : s) → M₁ i) (i : s)
```
should work, which tells lean you are casting from something that isn't a type.
Yup it works, I changed it ! Thanks !

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(LinearAlgebra/Multilinear/Basic): derivative of a multilinear map

nodes.body:
I took the liberty to label this PR by topic area, and tweak title and description to better match the standard format.
(Github's defaults are not always ideal here.)
Thanks !

> I took the liberty to [...] tweak the title [...] to better match the standard format

A very minor point: we don't put a space before the first `(`.

Remaining comments which cannot be posted as a review comment to avoid GitHub Rate Limit

<details>
<summary>lint-style</summary>

I pushed another file to my branch and it got added to the PR, even though that was not my intention (this other file needs some work before it can become a PR). Does anybody know how to reverse this, without touching the first file ?

I've discarded that file. Regarding what you attempt to do in the file: we have [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt) and [AnalyticAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#AnalyticAt) is defined in terms of [ContinuousMultilinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/Multilinear/Basic.html#ContinuousMultilinearMap). So I guess it shouldn't be hard to get what you want through that route?

> I've discarded that file. Regarding what you attempt to do in the file: we have [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt) and [AnalyticAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#AnalyticAt) is defined in terms of [ContinuousMultilinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/Multilinear/Basic.html#ContinuousMultilinearMap). So I guess it shouldn't be hard to get what you want through that route?

It depends what you mean by "not hard"; mathematically it's very easy, but in Lean it might be a pain. Certainly if I had known that analytic functions were in mathlib, I would have tried to go that route, because this is the best way. (And yes, I did ask about what I wanted to do on Zulip before starting.)

> > I've discarded that file. Regarding what you attempt to do in the file: we have [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt) and [AnalyticAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#AnalyticAt) is defined in terms of [ContinuousMultilinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Module/Multilinear/Basic.html#ContinuousMultilinearMap). So I guess it shouldn't be hard to get what you want through that route?
> 
> It depends what you mean by "not hard"; mathematically it's very easy, but in Lean it might be a pain. Certainly if I had known that analytic functions were in mathlib, I would have tried to go that route, because this is the best way. (And yes, I did ask about what I wanted to do on Zulip before starting.)

Okay, I know what to do, I hope it won't be too painful.

I found [your Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Differentiability.20of.20bounded.20multilinear.20maps.20.3F) (cc @ocfnash) and I do recall seeing it before. However, I had no idea Analytic is defined in terms of multilinear maps, even though I did know it's in mathlib. I only became aware 2 weeks ago due to my involvement in the Hairer challenge, when I looked up the definition of Analytic when proving [evaluations of multivariate polynomials are analytic](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9138/commits/a285b7d9f14cab1758e6b483b3c2ce3843aea59c#diff-bfe5d0518e7c120eede815999c537da5265deb6dc656d384628065d022d2969fR311-R317). Sorry for being unable to connect the dots earlier and for the extra work!

> I found [your Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Differentiability.20of.20bounded.20multilinear.20maps.20.3F) (cc @ocfnash) and I do recall seeing it before. However, I had no idea Analytic is defined in terms of multilinear maps, even though I did know it's in mathlib. I only became aware 2 weeks ago due to my involvement in the Hairer challenge, when I looked up the definition of Analytic when proving [evaluations of multivariate polynomials are analytic](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9138/commits/a285b7d9f14cab1758e6b483b3c2ce3843aea59c#diff-bfe5d0518e7c120eede815999c537da5265deb6dc656d384628065d022d2969fR311-R317). Sorry for being unable to connect the dots earlier and for the extra work!

Eh, it's not your fault. So anyway, I proved that continuous multilinear maps are analytic, however, to deduce that they are differentiable, I need the target space F to be complete ! At least that's a hypothesis in [AnalyticAt.contDiffAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FDeriv/Analytic.html#AnalyticAt.contDiffAt), I haven't checked whether it's possible to remove it. 
But my old proof works without that extra hypothesis on F ! So I guess I should still PR it, and also PR the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic, now that it's written ?

That's nice! I only just worked out the informal argument why a continuous multilinear form f (of finitely many factors) is analytic; you need to compose it with the (linear) projections to obtain f(p1, ..., pn) and put that as the nth term in the power series. As for the completeness assumption, I think it's removable and [FormalMultilinearSeries.changeOrigin_eval](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Analytic/Basic.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.changeOrigin_eval) seems to be the key lemma to generalize. I'll try later if you don't beat me to it!

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#9137~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I now realized that the derivative of an analytic function may not even exist if the space isn't complete, let alone continuously differentiable; the original series converging can't guarantee the derivative doesn't fall into a hole. So I think your result for continuous linear maps will be a valuable addition to mathlib! Maybe we could generalize it to analytic functions with finitely many nonzero terms ("polynomial functions"?). As a different project, the derivative's power series is in mathlib as [FormalMultilinearSeries.shift](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/FormalMultilinearSeries.html#FormalMultilinearSeries.shift), but apparently no one has shown it evaluates to the derivative yet ...

Maybe we can still make use of the proofs of the Analytic lemmas; you may try to replace the CompleteSpace conditions by the necessary Summable conditions. Then they'll apply to both CompleteSpaces (where we can use [Summable.of_norm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/InfiniteSum.html#Summable.of_norm)) and our situation ("polynomial functions"), where we have summability by virtue of being finite sums.

Yes, the completeness is only really used to prove the convergence of infinite power series. So maybe the simplest would be to have some HasFiniteFPowerSeriesOnBall structure which would cover both polynomial and multilinear functions. This should be stable by taking derivatives, and so we would get both analyticity and differentiability results with any completeness condition. I won't get to it today as I have a pretty full schedule.
By the way, the "continuous multilinear functions are analytic" code is [there](https://github.com/smorel394/ExteriorPowers/blob/master/ExteriorPowers/ContinuousMultilinearMapContDiff.lean).

Ok, I added some more stuff to prepare for the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic: the definition of what will be the formal multilinear series at `x` and a proof that it does calculate `f (x + y)` (with a finite sum). Also, the comparison of the degree `1` term with the previously defined derivative. I kept the previous derivative, because it definition doesn't use a linear order on `ι`, while the definition of the formal multilinear series does.

Also, I kept running into merge problems that for some reason duplicated the new code, so I hope that those are resolved now. It seems to be okay. And I broke mathlib in my branch when trying to update it (again :-(((( ), so nothing compiles locally for me, but I did check the new code in another lean project, and again hopefully it's okay. Now I'll try to fix my local mathlib.
Yeah, it's not okay, the thing didn't build. Why do I break stuff every time I update mathlib ? I only wanted the new lemma from PR #9137. :-(
(the base branches above are to work around a github quirk caused by a weird (but ultimately harmless) merge that you did)

Okay, after last night's git drama, and after a lot of help from Eric, and after I accidentally pushed the whole of mathlib4 to a mathlib3 branch, it seems that I have finally been able to successfully update this. So I added some code to prepare for the proof that continuous multilinear maps are analytic: the definition of what will be the formal multilinear series at x, i.e. the higher derivatives, and a proof that it does calculate f (x + y) (with a finite sum). Also, the comparison of the degree 1 term with the previously defined derivative. I kept the previous derivative, because it definition doesn't use a linear order on ι, while the definition of the formal multilinear series does.

As the new code uses things like `MultilinearMap.domDomCongr`, I moved it down in the file so it would come after that, and put it in its own section called 'Derivative`.
